revision.text:
[[File:El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar.png|thumb|375px|Locator map of the Gran Desierto de Altar,
in [[Sonora]], [[Northwest Mexico]].]] The '''Gran Desierto de Altar''' is one of the major sub-[[ecoregion]]s of the [[Sonoran Desert]], located in the [[Sonora|State of Sonora]], [[Northwest Mexico]]. It includes the only active [[Erg (landform)|erg]] dune region in [[North America]]. The desert extends across much of the northern border of the [[Gulf of California]], reaching more than {{convert|100|km|mi}} east to west, and over {{convert|50|km|mi}} north to south. It constitutes the largest continuous wilderness area within the Sonoran Desert. The eastern portion of the area contains the volcanic [[Pinacate Peaks]] region, and with the western Gran Desierto de Altar area, together they form the [[El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve]] and a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]].[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1410 UNESCO World Heritage Centre.] ==Geography== [[File:20091211 - Puerto Penasco -63.jpg|375px|thumb|Sand dunes at [[El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve]], northwestern Sonora, México.]] The Gran Desierto covers approximately {{convert|5700|sqkm}}, most of it in the Mexican state of Sonora. The northernmost edges overlap the border into [[Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument]] and [[Cabeza Prieta National Wildlife Refuge]] in southwestern [[Arizona]]. The dominant sand sheets and dunes range in thickness from less than {{convert|1|km|mi}} to greater than {{convert|12|km|mi}}. The total volume of sand in the Gran Desierto is about 60 cubic km. Most of that volume was delivered by the [[Pleistocene]] [[Colorado River]] which flowed through the present-day Gran Desierto area ~120,000 years before present. This Pleistocene [[River delta|delta]] migrated westward concomitant with [[strike-slip fault]]ing and [[rift]]ing associated with the opening of the [[Salton Trough]] and the [[Gulf of California]].Sykes, G., The Colorado Delta, Carnegie Institution/American Geographical Society, New York, 193 p., 1937a. ==Physiography== The eastern margin of the Gran Desierto abuts the [[Cenozoic]] [[volcanic]] complex of the [[Sierra Pinacate]], a composite volcanic field covering more than {{convert|1800|km|mi}}2 with a summit elevation of {{convert|1206|m|ft}}. [[Aeolian processes|Aeolian]] sands have climbed onto many of the western slopes of the Sierras Pinacate, defining the eastern limit of the dune field. To the north, the sands thin out against the distal margins of [[alluvial fan]]s from the [[Tinajas Altas]] and [[Tule Mountains]] along the Arizona-Sonora border. The southern border of the sand sea is the northern shore of the Gulf of California. The southernmost extension of the [[San Andreas Fault]] cuts across the area and lies beneath several prominent [[granite]] [[inselberg]]s, most notably the Sierra del Rosario mountains which are surrounded by the erg on all sides. The Sierra Enternada is a smaller inselberg almost completely buried by the sand near the boundary of the Gran Desierto and the [[Pinacate Peaks|Pinacate volcanic complex]]. ==Sand dune distribution== The Gran Desierto is best known for its magnificent Star Dunes, many in excess of {{convert|100|m|ft}} high. More than two-thirds of the Gran Desierto is covered by sand sheets and sand streaks. The remaining area is split equally between a western population of [[star dune]]s and an eastern set of transverse or crescentic dunes. Some of the larger [[Dune#Crescentic|crescentic dune]]s in the northeastern sand sea exhibit reversing crests, a transitional morphologic feature associated with star dunes. ==Flora== {{see also|List of flora of the Sonoran Desert Region by common name}} Vegetation assemblages of the Gran Desierto are typical of the lower Sonoran Desert with a marked difference in vegetation type and density with location. Large areas of the southern and eastern sand sea, especially near the margins, have a moderately dense (up to 20%) cover of perennial low shrubs and herbs such as bursage (''[[Ambrosia dumosa]]'') and longleaf jointfir (''[[Ephedra trifurca]]'') with creosote bush (''[[Larrea tridentata]]'') in areas of thin sand cover. [[Parkinsonia|Palo verde]]/[[acacia]]/[[Fouquieria splendens|ocotillo]] communities occur on alluvial slopes on the northern side of the sand sea, particularly in [[arroyo (creek)|arroyos]] and washes.Felger, R.S., Vegetation and flora of the Gran Desierto, Sonora, Mexico, Desert Plants, 2, 87-114, 1980. Its estimated total vegetation cover at 15% in the star dunes and about 10% in the low transverse or crescentic dunes areas. These percentages are substantially greater than in most active dune fields where vegetation covers of 15% are more typical.[Seely and Louw, 1980] Several teams have examined the nests ([[Pack rat#Midden|middens]]) built by [[pack rat]]s as a proxy for ancient vegetation regimes.Van Devender, T.R. and Spaulding, W.G., Development of vegetation and climate in the southwestern United States, Science, 204, 701-710, 1979.Hall, W.E., Van Devender, T.R. and Olson, C.A., Late Quaternary arthropod remains from Sonoran desert packrat middens, southwestern Arizona and northwestern Sonora, Quaternary Research, in press, 1988. All have concluded that the Gran Desierto has been a refugia for desert plants since at least the late Pleistocene. The Gran Desierto has served as a refuge for most dominant [[Mojave Desert]] plant species during cooler pluvial epochs as well. [[Carbon-14 dating|C14 dates]] for a midden from the [[Tinajas Altas Mountains]] showing assemblages of [[juniper]] and [[Yucca brevifolia|Joshua trees]] coexisting with contemporary Gran Desierto flora and fauna more than 43,000 years before present. Although midden studies do not provide information beyond the late Pleistocene, they do indicate that, in gross form, the climate of the Gran Desierto as recorded by plant communities has been desert-like since at least the peak of the [[Wisconsinan glaciation]]. ==Fauna== :See articles in: [[:Category:Fauna of the Sonoran Desert|Fauna of the Sonoran Desert]] ==Climate== The Gran Desierto has a warm-to-hot [[arid climate]]. Mean annual rainfall, most of which occurs between September and December, is 73 mm at [[Puerto Peñasco]], Sonora (located on the southeastern margin of the sand sea) and decreases northward toward [[Yuma, Arizona]] (on the northwestern edge) to 62 mm per year.Lancaster, N., Greeley, R. and Christensen, P.R., Dunes of the Gran Desierto sand sea, Sonora, Mexico, ''[[Earth Surface Processes and Landforms]]'', 12, 277 -288, 1987. Mid-summer highs in excess of 45 °C are common in the central sand sea. Mid-winter lows of less than 10 °C are rare. Winds are controlled in part by the position and strength of the [[Sonoran Low]] in summer, creating southerly winds, and by the [[Great Basin High]] in winter, with north-to-northeasterly winds. ==Paleoclimate== The well-documented [[pluvial]] epochs which occurred over much of the southwestern United States during the most-recent ([[Wisconsin glaciation|Wisconsin]]) [[ice age]] may not have extended as far south as the Gran Desierto.Spaulding, W.G., Leopold, E.B. and Van Devender, T.R., Late Wisconsin paleoecology of the American Southwest, in, Wright, H.E., Jr., ed., Late Quaternary Environments of the United States, v. 1, Univ. of Minnesota Press, 259-293, 1983. It appears that the climatic regime of the past 150,000 years at this site has been one of gradually increasing aridity with current hyperarid conditions being firmly in place by at least 43,000 years ago. As a minimum, it may be assumed that onshore coastal winds from the south were less important to sand movement when the Wisconsin shoreline was located 45 km seaward of its current position. ==Tectonics== The Gran Desierto is located adjacent to a rapidly subsiding [[tectonic basin]], the [[Salton Sink|Salton Trough]], which is a northern extension of the Gulf of California, an embayment created by rifting initiated during the [[Pliocene]] along the [[East Pacific Rise]] and the [[San Andreas fault]] system Larson, R.L., Menard, H.W. and Smith, S., Gulf of California: A result of ocean floor spreading and transform faulting, Science, 161, 881-884, 1968.Angelier, J., Colleta, B., Chorowicz, J., Ortlieb, L. and Rangin, C., Fault tectonics of the Baja California peninsula and the opening of the Sea of Cortez, Mexico, Journal of Structural Geology, 3, 347- 357, 1981. Regional subsidence has propagated to the northwest as rifting and strike-slip faulting continues into the present day. The central portion of the nearby Salton Trough is more than {{convert|70|m|ft}} below [[sea level]]; it is protected from marine embayment only by the natural dike of the [[Colorado River Delta]]. Ongoing tectonic activity modifies the Gran Desierto today. The southernmost extension of the San Andreas fault system, the [[Cerro Prieto Fault]], passes directly through the area before continuing offshore into the Gulf of California.Merriam, R., San Jacinto fault in northwestern Sonora, Mexico, Bull. G.S.A., 76, 1965. Strike-slip movement in the area is as high as 60 mm/year.Curray, J.R. and Moore, D.G., Geologic history of the mouth of the Gulf of California, in, Crouch, J.K. and Bachman, S.B., eds., Tectonics and Sedimentation along the California Margin, Pacific Section-S.E.P.M., 17-36, 1984. Gastil, R.G., Phillips, R.P. and Allison, E.C., Reconnaissance geology of the state of Baja California, G.S.A. Mem. 140, 170 p., 1975. Since 1900, one magnitude 6.3 and two magnitude 7.1 [[earthquake]]s have originated within the erg. Most seismicity within the Gran Desierto originates at depths of five to six kilometers, corresponding to the transition between [[River delta#Sedimentary structure|deltaic deposits]] and [[Basement (geology)|basement]] [[crystalline rock]]s.Von der Haar, S. and Howard, J.H., Intersecting faults and sandstone stratigraphy at the Cerro Prieto geothermal field, Geothermics, 10, 145-167, 1981. Local [[Tectonic uplift|uplift]] is still occurring along the [[Mesa Arenosa]], a drag folded fault block forming the coastal boundary. ==Origin== The geological history of the Gran Desierto is intimately linked to the opening of the Gulf of California and the capture of the ancestral Colorado River; source areas that were adjacent to the Gran Desierto have shifted in position, basement topography has been altered continuously, and bedforms have been created, modified or completely destroyed and then reworked. The Gran Desierto sand sheets and dunes are located atop deltaic deposits of the Pleistocene Colorado River. The lower Colorado River was captured by the Gulf of California 1.2 million years before present.Lucchitta, I., History of the Grand Canyon and of the Colorado River in Arizona, Az. Geol. Soc., in press, 15 p., 1988. This event places an upper bound on the age of the Gran Desierto with the Colorado's major [[clastic sediment]] sources. [[Conglomerate (geology)|Conglomeritic]] sands and silts beneath the Mesa Arenosa were examined by Colletta and Ortlieb and dated at between 700,000 and 120,000 years before present.Colleta, B. and Ortlieb, L., Deformations of middle and late Pleistocene deltaic deposits at the mouth of the Rio Colorado, northwestern Gulf of California, in Malpica-Cruz, V. et al.(eds.), Neotectonics and sea level variations in the Gulf of California area: A symposium, University Nacional Auton Mexico, Institute Geolocia, 31-53, 1984. [[Vertebrate]] [[fossil]]s found by Merriam within the deltaic deposits include [[Equus (genus)|Equus]], [[Gomphotherium]] and [[Bison]] and were assigned to [[Irvingtonian]] age (0.5 to 1.8 million years before present); dates consistent with the aforementioned capture of the lower Colorado River.Merriam [1965] Evidence of a [[giant anteater]] [[Myrmecophaga tridactyla]] was found in the deltaic deposits in the southern Gran Desierto. Van Devender notes that the specimen was found in association with fossils of [[mammoth]]s, [[sloth]]s and [[boa constrictor]]s; a tropical [[faunal assemblage]] which supports a contention that the Colorado River delta of a previous [[interglacial period]] (>120,000 years ago) was much warmer and wetter than the present interglacial.Shaw, C.A. and McDonald, H.G., First record of Giant Anteater (Xenarthra, Myrmecophagidae) in North America, Science, 236, 186-188, 1987. Paleo-deltaic deposits near [[Salina Grande]] correlate with a ubiquitous indurated shell deposit dated by Io/U [[Radiometric dating|radiometric methods]] at 146,000 + 13,000/-11, 000 years of age. Slate obtained [[Potassium-argon dating|K-Ar ages]] for [[basalt]] flows in the western Pinacates.Slate, J.L., Soil-Carbonate genesis in the Pinacate volcanic field, northwestern Sonora, Mexico, M.S. thesis, University of Arizona, Tucson, 85 p., 1985 Based on this work, some aeolian activity may have been present as early as 700,000 years ago, as evidenced by the dated accretionary mantles on basalt flows of the Pinacate volcanic field. Blount and Lancaster proposed that by late Pleistocene time, the Colorado River was a highly competent stream flowing through the area which is occupied today by the massive western star dune zone.Blount, Grady and Nicholas Lancaster, Development of the Gran Desierto sand sea, northwestern Mexico, Geology, v. 18, pp. 724–728, 1990. The seashore at this time was at least {{convert|45|km|mi}} south of its present-day location. Primary bed loads of poorly sorted gravel were deposited from present-day Yuma, Arizona to an area south of the present-day Sierra del Rosario mountains. As rifting of the Gulf of California progressed to the northwest, and uplift along the coast began, the river channel shifted westward, leaving primary bedload deposits in the former channel and floodplain. Deltaic sediments beneath the Gran Desierto may be as much as {{convert|6000|km|mi}} deep.Biehler, S., Kovach, R.L. and Allen, C.R., Geophysical framework of the northern end of the Gulf of California structural province, in Marine Geology of the Gulf of California, van Andel, T .H. and Shor, G.G., eds., A.A.P.G., Memoir 3, 126-143, 1964. Annual sediment loads prior to the damming of the Colorado River were prodigious. A single flood event deposited an estimated 100,000,000 m3 of coarse to medium sand as a sheet deposit on the modern delta just south of the international boundary.Sykes, G., Delta, estuary, and lower portion of the channel of the Colorado River, 1933 to 1935, Carnegie Institution, New York, 76 p., 1937b. Events like this, even if rare, could fill up the Gran Desierto in only a few millennia. ==Offshore features== The synchronous development of the [[Colorado River Delta]] and the associated Gran Desierto sand sink continues offshore into the Gulf of California. Reports on the submarine [[topography]] of the Gulf of California by van Andel, describe three former [[river channel]]s on the [[seafloor]]: one originating at the present-day Colorado delta, another from the area of the paleo-delta between El Golfo and Salina Grande, and a third to the area of present-day [[Puerto Penasco]].van Andel, T.H., Recent marine sediments of Gulf of California, in Marine Geology of the Gulf of California, van Andel, T.H. and Shor, G.G., eds., A.A.P .G., Memoir 3, 216-310, 1964. Rusnak reported on sonar soundings which discovered the valleys and also describe two elongate depressions, each about {{convert|40|km|mi}} in length, into which the valley networks terminate at a depth of ~{{convert|180|m|ft}} below sea level. Those incised valley systems were also interpreted as [[fluvial]] in origin.Ruznak, G.A. and Fisher, R.L., Structural history and evolution of the Gulf of California, in Marine Geology of the Gulf of California, van Andel, T.H. and Shor, G.G., eds., A.A.P .G., Memoir 3, 144-156, 1964. ==See also== *[[El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve]] **[[Pinacate Peaks]] *[[Sonoran Desert]] **[[:Category:Flora of the Sonoran Deserts|Flora of the Sonoran Deserts]] **[[Lechuguilla Desert]] **[[Yuma Desert]] **[[Colorado Desert]] *[[Chihuahuan Desert]] ==References== {{Reflist|3}} *Biehler, S., Kovach, R.L. and Allen, C.R., Geophysical framework of the northern end of the Gulf of California structural province, in Marine Geology of the Gulf of California, van Andel, T .H. and Shor, G.G., eds., A.A.P.G., Memoir 3, 126-143, 1964. *Guzman, A.E., Petroleum possibilities in Altar Desert, Sonora, Mexico, abs., A.A.P .G., 64, 716, 1980. *MacDougal, D.T., Across Papagueria, Bull. American Geographical Soc., 40, 705-725, 1908. ==External links== {{Wikivoyage|Altar Desert}} {{commons category|El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar}} *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1410 World Heritage Centre: Official UNESCO '''El Pinacate and Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve''' website] *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1410/gallery/ UNESCO: Photo gallery of Reserve] *[http://elpinacate.conanp.gob.mx ElPinacate.gob.mx: '''Reserva de la Biosfera El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar'''] *[http://elpinacate.conanp.gob.mx/historia.php ElPinacate.gob.mx: "Historia" (la ocupación humana)] {{Coord|31.95|-114.14|display=title}} {{Deserts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gran Desierto De Altar}} [[Category:Gran Desierto de Altar| 01]] [[Category:Sonoran Desert]] [[Category:Deserts of Mexico]] [[Category:Deserts and xeric shrublands]] [[Category:Ecoregions of Mexico]] [[Category:Dunes of Mexico]] [[Category:Ergs]] [[Category:Geography of Sonora]] [[Category:Gulf of California]] [[Category:Natural history of Sonora]] [[Category:Landforms of Sonora]]

revision.text:
:''For the soil scientist, see [[Hans Jenny (pedologist)]].
'''Hans Jenny''' (16 August 1904, [[Basel]] – 23 June 1972, [[Dornach]]) was a [[physician]] and [[natural scientist]] who coined the term [[cymatics]] to describe acoustic effects of [[sound wave]] phenomena.
==Life and career== Jenny was born in [[Basel]], Switzerland. After completing a [[doctorate]] he taught [[science]] at the [[Rudolph Steiner School]] in [[Zürich]] for four years before beginning [[medicine|medical practice]].
In 1967, Jenny published the first volume of ''Cymatics: The Study of Wave Phenomena.'' The second volume came out in 1972, the year he died. This book was a written and photographic documentation of the effects of sound [[vibration]]s on [[fluid]]s, [[Powder (substance)|powders]] and liquid paste. He concluded, "This is not an unregulated [[Chaos theory|chaos]]; it is a dynamic but ordered pattern."
Jenny made use of crystal [[oscillator]]s and his so-called [[tonoscope]] to set plates and [[artificial membrane|membrane]]s vibrating. He spread [[quartz]] sand onto a black drum membrane 60 cm in diameter. The membrane was caused to vibrate by [[singing]] loudly through a cardboard pipe, and the sand produced [[symmetry|symmetrical]] [[Chladni patterns]], named after [[Ernst Chladni]], who had discovered this phenomenon in 1787. Low [[Pitch (music)|tones]] resulted in rather simple and clear pictures, while higher tones formed more complex structures.<ref name="deschin">Deschin, Jacob (April 28, 1968). Science Vibrates to Make Pictures. ''[[New York Times]]''</ref>
==Legacy== Chladni's and Jenny's work influenced [[Alvin Lucier]] and helped lead to his composition ''Queen of the South''. Cymatics was also followed up by [[Center for Advanced Visual Studies]] (CAVS) founder [[György Kepes]] at [[MIT]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/cavs/people/kepes/kepes.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2002-11-04 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021104072629/http://web.mit.edu/cavs/people/kepes/kepes.html |archivedate=November 4, 2002 |df= }}</ref> His work in this area included an [[Acoustics|acoustically]] vibrated piece of sheet metal in which small holes had been drilled in a grid. Small flames of gas burned through these holes and [[thermodynamic]] patterns were made visible by this setup. A special edition of the [[Hafler Trio]]'s work ''Exactly As I Say'' includes a DVD containing material said to be "based on and extended from techniques suggested by Prof. Hans Jenny". Photographer [[Alexander Lauterwasser]] has also captured imagery of water surfaces set into motion by sound sources ranging from [[sine wave]]s to music by [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]], [[Karlheinz Stockhausen]] and [[overtone singing]].
== Publications == * 1954: ''Der Typus'' (The Type) a study in [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] * 1962: ''Das Gesetz der Wiederholung'' (The laws of Repetition) * 1967: ''Kymatic'' (Cymatics) Volume 1 * 1972: ''Kymatic'' (Cymatics) Volume 2
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090710023836/http://cymatica.net/ Cymatica.net : Architectural thesis investigation into the synthesis of space and form generated from sound]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jenny, Hans}} [[Category:1904 births]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:People from Basel-Stadt]] [[Category:Swiss physicians]] [[Category:Natural scientists]] [[Category:Swiss scientists]] [[Category:Anthroposophists]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=January 2012}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2016}}
'''IEC 61850''' is an international standard defining communication protocols for [[intelligent electronic device]]s at [[electrical substation]]s. It is a part of the [[International Electrotechnical Commission|International Electrotechnical Commission's]] (IEC) [[IEC TC 57|Technical Committee 57]]<ref>[http://tc57.iec.ch Technical Committee 57 (TC57)]</ref> reference architecture for [[electric power]] systems. The abstract data models defined in IEC 61850 can be mapped to a number of protocols. Current mappings in the standard are to MMS ([[Manufacturing Message Specification]]), [[GOOSE]] (Generic Object Oriented Substation Event), SMV (Sampled Measured Values),{{clarify|date=January 2012}} and soon to [[Web Services]]. These protocols can run over [[TCP/IP]] networks or substation [[LAN]]s using high speed switched [[Ethernet]] to obtain the necessary response times below four milliseconds for protective relaying.
==History== Multiple protocols exist for substation automation, which include many proprietary protocols with custom communication links. Interoperation of devices from different vendors would be an advantage to users of substation automation devices. An IEC project group of about 60 members from different countries worked in three IEC working groups from 1995. They responded to all the concerns and objectives and created IEC 61850. The objectives set for the standard were: # A single protocol for complete substation considering modelling of different data required for substation # Definition of basic services required to transfer data so that the entire mapping to communication protocol can be made future proof # Promotion of high inter-operability between systems from different vendors # A common method/format for storing complete data # Define complete testing required for the equipment which conforms to the standard
==Standard documents== IEC 61850 consists of the following parts detailed in separate IEC 61850 standard documents: * IEC TR 61850-1:2013 - Introduction and overview * IEC TS 61850-2:2003 - Glossary * IEC 61850-3:2013 - General requirements * IEC 61850-4:2011 - System and project management * IEC 61850-5:2013 - Communication requirements for functions and device models * IEC 61850-6:2009 - Configuration language for communication in electrical substations related to IEDs * IEC 61850-7-1:2011 - Basic communication structure - Principles and models * IEC 61850-7-2:2010 - Basic communication structure - Abstract communication service interface (ACSI) * IEC 61850-7-3:2010 - Basic communication structure - Common Data Classes * IEC 61850-7-4:2010 - Basic communication structure - Compatible logical node classes and data classes * IEC 61850-7-410:2012 - Basic communication structure - Hydroelectric power plants - Communication for monitoring and control * IEC 61850-7-420:2009 - Basic communication structure - Distributed energy resources logical nodes * IEC TR 61850-7-510:2012 - Basic communication structure - Hydroelectric power plants - Modelling concepts and guidelines * IEC 61850-8-1:2011 - Specific communication service mapping (SCSM) - Mappings to [[Manufacturing Message Specification]] MMS (ISO 9506-1 and ISO 9506-2) and to ISO/IEC 8802-3 * IEC 61850-9-2:2011 - Specific communication service mapping (SCSM) - Sampled values over ISO/IEC 8802-3 * [[IEC/IEEE 61850-9-3]]:2016 - [[Precision time protocol]] profile for power utility automation * IEC 61850-10:2012 - [[Conformance testing]] * IEC TS 61850-80-1:2016 - Guideline to exchanging information from a CDC-based data model using IEC 60870-5-101 or IEC 60870-5-104 * IEC TR 61850-80-3:2015 - Mapping to web protocols - Requirements and technical choices * IEC TS 61850-80-4:2016 - Translation from the COSEM object model (IEC 62056) to the IEC 61850 data model * IEC TR 61850-90-1:2010 - Use of IEC 61850 for the communication between substations * IEC TR 61850-90-2:2016 - Using IEC 61850 for communication between substations and control centres * IEC TR 61850-90-3:2016 - Using IEC 61850 for condition monitoring diagnosis and analysis * IEC TR 61850-90-4:2013 - Network engineering guidelines * IEC TR 61850-90-5:2012 - Use of IEC 61850 to transmit synchrophasor information according to IEEE C37.118 * IEC TR 61850-90-7:2013 - Object models for power converters in distributed energy resources (DER) systems * IEC TR 61850-90-8:2016 - Object model for E-mobility * IEC TR 61850-90-12:2015 - Wide area network engineering guidelines
==Features== IEC 61850 features include: # ''[[Data Modeling]]'' — Primary process objects as well as protection and control functionality in the substation is modelled into different standard logical nodes which can be grouped under different logical devices. There are logical nodes for data/functions related to the logical device (''LLN0'') and physical device (''LPHD''). # ''Reporting Schemes'' — There are various reporting schemes (''BRCB & URCB'') for reporting data from server through a server-client relationship which can be triggered based on pre-defined trigger conditions. # ''Fast Transfer of events'' — [[Generic Substation Events]] (''GSE'') are defined for fast transfer of event data for a peer-to-peer communication mode. This is again subdivided into ''[[GOOSE]]'' & [[Generic Substation Events#Generic Substation State Events (GSSE)|''GSSE'']]. # ''Setting Groups'' — The setting group control Blocks (''SGCB'') are defined to handle the setting groups so that user can switch to any active group according to the requirement. # ''Sampled Data Transfer'' — Schemes are also defined to handle transfer of sampled values using Sampled Value Control blocks (''SVCB'') # ''Commands'' — Various command types are also supported by IEC 61850 which include direct & select before operate (SBO) commands with normal and enhanced securities. # ''Data Storage'' — [[Substation Configuration Language]] (''SCL'') is defined for complete storage of configured data of the substation in a specific format.
==Related standards== * IEC 61850-7-410 — Hydroelectric Power Plants - Communication for monitoring and control. [Published] * IEC 61850-7-420 — Communications systems for [[Distributed Energy Resources]] (DER) - Logical nodes [Published] * IEC 61850-7-500 — Use of logical nodes to model functions of a substation Automation system. [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-7-510 — Use of logical nodes to model functions of a Hydro Power Plant. [Published] * IEC 61850-90-1 — Use of IEC 61850 for the communication between substations [Published] * IEC 61850-90-2 — Use of IEC 61850 for the communication between control centres and substations [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-90-3 — Using IEC 61850 for Condition Monitoring [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-90-4 — IEC 61850 - Network Engineering Guidelines [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-90-5 — Use of IEC 61850 to transmit synchrophasor information according to IEEE C37.118 [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-90-6 — Use of IEC 61850 for Distribution Feeder Automation System [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-90-7 — Object Models for Photovoltaic,Storage and other DER inverters [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-90-8 — Object Models for Electrical Transportation (E-Mobility [Approved New Work]) * IEC 61850-90-9 — Object Models for Batteries [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-90-10 — Object Models for Scheduling [Approved New Work] * IEC 61850-80-1 — Guideline to exchanging information from a CDC-based data model using IEC 60870-5-101 or IEC 60870-5-104 [Published] * [[IEC 61400-25]] — Application of the IEC 61850 methodology for [[Wind turbine]]s ** IEC 61400-25-1 — Wind turbines - Part 25-1: Communications for monitoring and control of wind power plants - Overall description of principles and models [Published] ** IEC 61400-25-2 — Wind turbines - Part 25-2: Communications for monitoring and control of wind power plants - Information models [Published] ** IEC 61400-25-3 — Wind turbines - Part 25-3: Communications for monitoring and control of wind power plants - Information exchange models [Published] ** IEC 61400-25-4 — Wind turbines - Part 25-4: Communications for monitoring and control of wind power plants - Mapping to communication profile *** Mapping to [[SOAP]]-based [[Web Service]] [Published] *** Mapping to [[Manufacturing Message Specification|MMS]] [Published] *** Mapping to [[OLE for process control|OPC]] [[XML]] [Published] *** Mapping to [[IEC 60870-5-104]] [Published] *** Mapping to [[DNP3]] [Published] ** IEC 61400-25-5 — Wind turbines - Part 25-5: Communications for monitoring and control of wind power plants - Conformance testing [Published] ** IEC 61400-25-6 — Wind Turbines - Part 25-6: Communications for monitoring and control of wind power plants - Logical node classes and data classes for condition monitoring [Published] * IEC 61869-9 — Instrument transformers - Part 9: Digital interface for instrument transformers [Published] * IEC 62271-3 — Communications for monitoring and control of high-voltage [[switchgear]] (published)
==See also== * [[Generic Substation Events]] (GSE) * [[IEC 61968]] * [[IEC 61970]] * [[IEC TC 57]] * [[OLE for process control]] * [[Substation Configuration Language]] (SCL)
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://webstore.iec.ch/searchform&q=61850 IEC Website for IEC 61850 standards] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100826005058/http://www.stri.se/wwwpublic/STRI-References-IEC61850.pdf STRI-Independent Interoperability Project for IEC 61850] * [http://seclab.illinois.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/iec61850-intro.pdf Detailed Introduction to IEC 61850] * [http://iec61850.tissue-db.com/parts.mspx IEC 61850 Technical Issues website] * [http://www.ucaiug.org/default.aspx UCA International Users Group] * [http://www.prosoft-technology.com/content/download/4576/32664/file/IEC61850_A-Protocol-with-Powerful-Potential.pdf IEC61850: A Protocol with Powerful Potential] * [https://www.bcit.ca/files/appliedresearch/pdf/ruggedcom_industry.pdf Perspectives and priorities on RuggedCom Smart Grid Research IEC 61850 Technologies] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120114222001/http://xn--61850-txen0l.xn--p1ai/wp-content/plugins/downloads-manager/upload/Introduction%20of%20Smart%20Subsltation%20Projects.pdf Projects with Smart Substation Solution] * [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/Xplore/login.jsp?url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fiel5%2F5619950%2F5621989%2F05622092.pdf%3Farnumber%3D5622092&authDecision=-203 Smart High Voltage Substation Based on IEC 61850 Process Bus and IEEE 1588 Time Synchronization] * [http://eprints.qut.edu.au/41257 Test and evaluation system for multi-protocol sampled value protection schemes by Dr. David M.E. Ingram]

page.title: List of Local Nature Reserves in Cambridgeshire

revision.comment: clean up, sp, replaced: Cambride → Cambridge
revision.text:
[[File:Byron's Pool 4.jpg|thumb|325px|[[Byron's Pool]]|alt=Byron's Pool]] [[Cambridgeshire]] is a county in eastern England, with an area of {{convert|1,308|sqmi|sqkm}} and a population as of 2011 of 708,719. It is crossed by two major rivers, the [[River Nene|Nene]] and the [[River Great Ouse|Great Ouse]]. The main manufacturing area is [[Peterborough]], and the foundation of the [[University of Cambridge]] in the thirteenth century made the county one of the country's most important intellectual centres. A large part of the county is in [[The Fens]], and drainage of this habitat, which was probably commenced in the Roman period and largely completed by the seventeenth century, considerably increased the area available for agriculture.{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Cambridgeshire|title=Cambridgeshire|publisher=Encyclopedia Britannica|year=2013|accessdate=17 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011224415/https://www.britannica.com/place/Cambridgeshire|archivedate=11 October 2016|df=}} The administrative county was formed in 1974, incorporating most of the historic county of [[Huntingdonshire]]. Local government is divided between [[Cambridgeshire County Council]] and [[Peterborough City Council]], which is a separate [[Unitary authorities of England|unitary authority]]. Under the county council, there are five district councils, [[Cambridge City Council]], [[South Cambridgeshire District Council]], [[East Cambridgeshire District Council]], [[Huntingdonshire District Council]] and [[Fenland District Council]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/info/20050/council_structure/81/local_government_in_cambridgeshire|title=Local government in Cambridgeshire|publisher=Cambridgeshire County Council|accessdate=25 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819221806/http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/info/20050/council_structure/81/local_government_in_cambridgeshire|archivedate=19 August 2016|df=}} [[Local Nature Reserve]]s (LNRs) are designated by local authorities, which must have a legal control over the site, by owning or leasing it or having an agreement with the owner. LNRs are sites which have a special local interest either biologically, geologically or education. Local authorities can either manage sites themselves or through other groups such as "friends of" and wildlife trusts, and can apply local [[Byelaws in the United Kingdom|bye-laws]] to manage and protect LNRs.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/guidance/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|title=Local Nature Reserves: Setting up and Management|date=2 October 2014|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=17 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118052129/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|archivedate=18 January 2017|df=}} There are twenty-seven LNRs in Cambridgeshire.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=5&Submit=Search|title=Search Results for Cambridgeshire|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=25 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816113439/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=5&Submit=Search|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} Four are [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]], and five are managed by the [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]]. The largest is [[Little Paxton Pits]] at sixty hectares, which is of national importance for wintering wildfowl, and the smallest is [[St Denis Church, East Hatley|St Denis Churchyard, East Hatley]], which has grassland with diverse flowers. There is public access to all sites. {{kml}} ==Key== ===Other classifications=== * '''SSSI''' = [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] * '''WTBCN''' = [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]] ==Sites== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- !scope="col" | Site !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph !scope="col" data-sort-type="number"| Area{{efn|Unless otherwise stated, the area is taken from the Natural England map of each site. (Click on the identify icon ('''i''') in the "Feature Tools" and then click on the site.){{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=5&Submit=Search|title=Local Nature Reserves: Search Results for Cambridgeshire|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=26 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816113439/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=5&Submit=Search|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} }} !scope="col" | Location{{efn|The location is taken from the Natural England details page for the site.}} !scope="col" |Borough !scope="col" |Other classifications !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are on the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.}} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Details{{efn|Details are on the pages on each site in the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.}} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"|[[Barnwell East]] |[[File:Barnwell East 1.jpg|100px|alt=Barnwell East]] |{{convert| 2.6 |ha|acre}} | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord| 52.203 | 0.161 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Barnwell East }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 478 583 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008762%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=23 Details] |The site has woodland, a pond, scrub and grassland. Flora include [[blackthorn]]s, [[Crataegus monogyna|hawthorns]] and [[Ophrys apifera|bee orchids]], there are birds such as [[blackcap]]s and [[willow warbler]]s, and [[common blue]] and [[meadow brown]] butterflies.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=23|title=Barnwell East|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=20 February 2013|accessdate=26 October 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022220457/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=23|archivedate=22 October 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Barnwell West]] |[[File:Barnwell II West 4.jpg|100px|alt=Barnwell II West]] |{{convert| 3.8 |ha|acre}} | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord| 52.204 | 0.161 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Barnwell II West }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 478 584 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009453%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=789 Details] |This is a linear site along [[Coldhams Brook]], which is managed to encourage [[European water vole|water voles]]. There are birds such as [[Common kingfisher|kingfishers]], [[redwing]]s and [[fieldfare]]s, and butterflies include [[Speckled wood (butterfly)|speckled woods]] and [[Anthocharis cardamines|orange tips]].{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=789|title= Barnwell II West|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 20 February 2013|accessdate= 26 October 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160816112752/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=789|archivedate= 16 August 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Beechwoods]] |[[File:Beechwoods Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 604834.jpg|100px|alt=The Beechwoods]] |{{convert| 9.8 |ha|acre}} | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord| 52.167 | 0.170 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= The Beechwoods }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 485 545 }} |[[Cambridge]] |[[WTBCN]]{{cite web |url= http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/beechwoods |title= Beechwoods |publisher= Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate= 14 December 2016 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170222180747/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/beechwoods |archivedate= 22 February 2017 |df= dmy-all }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009188%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=453 Details] |Beeches were planted on chalky farmland in the 1840s, and medieval plough terraces are still visible. Birds include [[Picus viridis|green]] and [[great spotted woodpecker]]s, and [[Sitta europaea|nuthatches]]. |- ! scope="row"|{{sortname|The| Boardwalks|The Boardwalks}} |[[File:The Boardwalks 4.jpg|100px|alt=The Boardwalks]] |{{convert| 7.8 |ha|acre}} | [[Peterborough]]
{{coord| 52.569 | -0.260 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= The Boardwalks }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 180 982 }} |[[Peterborough]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009189%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=454 Details] |The site runs along the north bank of the [[River Nene]]. It has ponds with water beetles, frogs, toads and [[smooth newt]]s. Bats nest in large willows, and birds include herons and woodpeckers.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=454|title=The Boardwalks|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=21 February 2013|accessdate=1 November 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816110124/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=454|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bramblefields]] |[[File:Pond on Bramblefields local nature reserve - geograph.org.uk - 605220.jpg|100px|alt=Bramblefields]] |{{convert| 2.1|ha|acre}} | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord| 52.224 | 0.154 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bramblefields }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 472 606 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009844%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=908 Details] |This site in the middle of a residential area has grassland, scrub and a pond with invertebrates such as frogs and newts. Birds include [[song thrush]]es.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=908|title= Bramblefields|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 20 February 2013|accessdate= 14 December 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160816144424/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=908|archivedate= 16 August 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Byron's Pool]] |[[File:Byron's Pool - geograph.org.uk - 652247.jpg|100px|alt=Byron's Pool]] |{{convert| 4.4 |ha|acre}} | [[Grantchester]]
{{coord| 52.167 | 0.136 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Byron's Pool }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 461 542 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271084814%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1123 Details] |The site is named after [[Lord Byron]], who used to swim in the pool. It is a linear pond and woodland next to the [[River Cam]]. Birds include [[little grebe]]s and [[grey wagtail]]s, and there are frogs, butterflies, damselflies and dragonflies.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1123|title= Byron's Pool|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 20 February 2013|accessdate= 26 October 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160816103948/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1123|archivedate= 16 August 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Coldham's Common]] |[[File:Coldham's Common - geograph.org.uk - 867534.jpg|100px|alt=Coldham's Common]] |{{convert| 49.3 |ha|acre}} | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord|52.206 |0.153 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Coldham's Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 472 586 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271475797%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1716 Details] |This site has areas of unimproved grassland, with anthills of [[yellow meadow ant]]s.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1716|title= Coldham's Common|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 20 February 2013|accessdate= 26 October 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160816121940/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1716|archivedate= 16 August 2016|df= }} There is also scrub and woodland. Flora includes [[Ononis spinosa|spiny rest harrow]], [[upright brome]] and [[Ophrys apifera|bee orchid]].{{cite web|url=http://lnr.cambridge.gov.uk/nature_reserve/coldhams-common/|title=Coldham's Common|publisher=Cambridge City Council|accessdate=26 October 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026234357/http://lnr.cambridge.gov.uk/nature_reserve/coldhams-common/|archivedate=26 October 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Dogsthorpe Star Pit]] |[[File:Dogsthorpe8631.jpg|100px|alt=Dogsthorpe Star Pit]] |{{convert| 36.7 |ha|acre}} | [[Peterborough]]
{{coord| 52.608 | -0.210 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Dogsthorpe Star Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TF 213 026 }} |[[Peterborough]] |[[SSSI]], [[WTBCN]]{{cite web |url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/dogsthorpe-star-pit |title=Dogsthorpe Star Pit |publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate=30 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817060715/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/dogsthorpe-star-pit |archivedate=17 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271082882%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=999 Details] |This former brick pit has been designated an SSSI mainly for its invertebrates, especially its water beetles, with 64 species, including 4 on the [[IUCN Red List|IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]], ''Graptodytes bilineatus'', ''Dryops similaris'', ''Gyrinus distinctus'' and ''Myopites inulaedyssentericae''.{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006649.pdf|title= Dogsthorpe Star Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 30 November 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001509/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006649.pdf|archivedate= 4 March 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Eye Green Local Nature Reserve|Eye Green]] |[[File:Water-filled disused brick pit, Eye Green, Peterborough - geograph.org.uk - 62746.jpg|100px|alt=Eye Green]] |{{convert| 12.0 |ha|acre}} | [[Eye Green]]
{{coord| 52.614 | -0.185 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Eye Green }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TF 230 034 }} |[[Peterborough]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009263%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=530 Details] |This site was formerly brick workings, and a large area is now filled by a lake. Reeds and scrub line much of the shore, providing cover for water birds such coots and moorhens, while dunnock and great tits nest in dense scrub. There is grassland with many flowers, and diverse invertebrate species.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=530|title= Eye Green|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 20 February 2013|accessdate= 9 October 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160816111551/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=530|archivedate= 16 August 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Grimeshaw Wood]] |[[File:Grimeshaw Wood 3.jpg|100px|alt=Grimeshaw Wood]] |{{convert| 16.8 |ha|acre}} | [[Peterborough]]
{{coord| 52.594 | -0.289 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Grimeshaw Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TF 160 010 }} |[[Peterborough]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008924%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=186 Details] |This site is ancient woodland in three adjacent areas. Flora include [[nettle-leaved bellflower]]s, and there are resident [[pipistrelle bat]]s.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=186|title= Grimeshaw Wood|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 20 February 2013|accessdate= 1 November 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160816122452/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=186|archivedate= 16 August 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Isleham Nature Reserve|Isleham]] |[[File:Isleham Nature Reserve 1.jpg|100px|alt=Isleham Nature Reserve]] |{{convert| 1.1 |ha|acre}} | [[Isleham]]

It is grassland and hedgerows with a wide variety of fauna and flora. There are flowering plants such as [[field scabious]], [[greater knapweed]], [[St John's wort]], [[wild marjoram]] and [[bladder campion]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1654|title=Isleham|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=|accessdate=9 November 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816132419/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1654|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Kingston and Bourn Old Railway]] |[[File:Kingston and Bourn old railway Local Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 871131.jpg|100px|alt=Kingston and Bourn Old Railway]] |{{convert| 1.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Toft, Cambridgeshire|Toft]]
{{coord| 52.185 | -0.043 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Kingston and Bourn Old Railway }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 339 559 }} |[[South Cambridgeshire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271100047%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1371 Details] |The sides of this old railway bank are woodland, with ash, field maple and oak the main trees, while the top of the bank is unimproved grassland.{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/directory_record/3217/kingston_and_bourn_old_railway|title=Kingston and Bourn Old Railway|publisher=Cambridgeshire County Council|accessdate=14 December 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220163626/http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/directory_record/3217/kingston_and_bourn_old_railway|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=}} There is also an area of wetland with mature pollarded willows.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1371|title=Kingston and Bourn Old Railway|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=20 February 2013|accessdate=14 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816125924/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1371|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Lattersey Field]] |[[File:Raised walkway through the Lattersey Reserve, Cambridgeshire - geograph-3078615.jpg|100px|alt=Lattersey Field]] |{{convert| 11.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Whittlesey]]
{{coord| 52.552 | -0.111 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Lattersey Field }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 282 966 }} |[[Fenland District|Fenland]] |[[WTBCN]]{{cite web |url= http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/lattersey |title= Lattersey |publisher= Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate= 15 December 2016 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160817153346/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/lattersey |archivedate= 17 August 2016 |df= dmy-all }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008991%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=254 Details] |This former clay brick quarry has pits which have filled with water, and it has diverse habitats of grassland, woodland, scrub, pools, marshes and reedbeds. Mammals includes [[Arvicola amphibius|water voles]], [[Neomys fodiens|water shrews]], and there are birds such as [[Acrocephalus schoenobaenus|sedge warblers]], [[Strix aluco|tawny owls]], [[Scolopax rusticola|woodcocks]], [[great spotted woodpecker]]s and [[Emberiza schoeniclus|reed buntings]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=254|title=Lattersey Field|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=20 February 2013|accessdate=15 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816110705/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=254|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Limekiln Close and East Pit]] |[[File:East Pit 10.jpg|100px|alt=East Pit]] |{{convert| 11.0 |ha|acre}} | [[Cherry Hinton]]
{{coord| 52.182 |0.171 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Limekiln Close and East Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 485 560 }} |[[Cambridge]] |[[SSSI]], [[WTBCN]]{{cite web |url= http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/cherry-hinton |title= Cherry Hinton Chalk Pits |publisher= Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate= 30 November 2016 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20161224160137/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/cherry-hinton |archivedate= 24 December 2016 |df= dmy-all }} |N/Av{{efn|name=cherry|Three adjacent chalk pits in [[Cherry Hinton]] are nature reserves; East Pit and West Pit are separated by Limekiln Road, and the third pit called Limekiln Close is north of East Pit. Cambridge City Council have designated Limekiln Close and East Pit as one LNR, and West Pit as another one.{{cite web|url=https://www.cambridge.gov.uk/limekiln-close-and-east-pit-local-nature-reserve|title=Limekiln Close and East Pit Local Nature Reserve|publisher=Cambridge City Council|accessdate=15 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116182911/https://www.cambridge.gov.uk/limekiln-close-and-east-pit-local-nature-reserve|archivedate=16 January 2017|df=}} However, the LNRs are confused on the Natural England website. One LNR is shown as Limekiln Close and West Pit on the details page,{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=263|title=Limekiln Close and West Pit|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=20 February 2013|accessdate=15 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816144926/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=263|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} but the map only covers Limekiln Close.{{cite web|url=http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008999%27|title=Map of Limekiln Close and West Pit|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=15 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818075931/http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D'1008999'|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=}} The other LNR is shown on the details page as East Pit,{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=east%20pit&ID=1712 |title=East Pit |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=20 February 2013 |accessdate=15 January 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171125202635/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=east%20pit&ID=1712 |archivedate=25 November 2017 |df= }} whereas the map covers both East and West Pits.{{cite web|url=http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271475802%27|title=Map of East Pit|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=15 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818040810/http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D'1475802'|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=}} To add to the confusion, East and West Pits are designated an SSSI called Cherry Hinton Pit,{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000331.pdf |title=Cherry Hinton Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=15 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304043220/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000331.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }}{{cite web|url= http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271000331%27|title= Map of Cherry Hinton Pit|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 15 January 2017|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304024413/http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D'1000331'|archivedate= 4 March 2016|df= }} and Limekiln Close and East Pit are managed by the Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire as a nature reserve called Cherry Hinton Chalk Pits. }} |N/Av{{efn|name=cherry}} |The two parts of the site are both former chalk quarries. East Pit is surrounded by steep walls of chalk, and the base is wildflower grassland with areas of scrub. Flowers include [[Polygala vulgaris|millkwort]], [[Campanula rotundifolia|harebell]], [[Anthyllis vulneraria|kidney vetch]] and the rare [[Seseli libanotis|moon carrot]], which is on the British [[IUCN Red List|Red List of Threatened Species]]. Quarrying ceased 200 years ago in Limekiln Close, and it is now steeply sloping mature woodland with ash and cherry trees. |- ! scope="row"|[[Little Downham Local Nature Reserve|Little Downham]] |[[File:Little Downham Local Nature Reserve 2.jpg|100px|alt=Little Downham]] |{{convert| 6.6 |ha|acre}} | [[Little Downham]]
{{coord|52.427 | 0.234 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Little Downham }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 524 834 }} |[[East Cambridgeshire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009845%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1190 Details] |The site consists of three areas of land, Pingle Wood, Myles Meadow and The Holts. Myles Meadow has two ponds and is seasonally grazed by cattle. Holts Meadow has a pond with many dragonflies and damselflies, including the [[emperor (dragonfly)|emperor]] and [[scarce chaser]] dragonflies.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1190|title=Little Downham|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=21 February 2013|accessdate=14 November 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816115208/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1190|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Little Paxton Pits]] |[[File:Paxton Pits Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 1547986.jpg|100px|alt=Little Paxton Pits]] |{{convert| 60.0 |ha|acre}} | [[Little Paxton]]
{{coord| 52.258 | -0.243 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Little Paxton Pits }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 200 637 }} |[[Huntingdonshire]] |[[SSSI]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009006%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=270 Details] |These flooded former gravel pits are of national importance for wintering wildfowl, especially [[Anas strepera|gadwalls]]. There are several nationally rare flies, such as ''[[Spilogona scutulata]]'' and ''[[Lispocephala falculata]]''. Flora include [[common spotted-orchid]]s and [[Trifolium arvense|hare’s-foot clover]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002350.pdf|title=Little Paxton Pits citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=11 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061722/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002350.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Logan's Meadow]] |[[File:Big Bird in a Small Pond - geograph.org.uk - 713965.jpg|100px|alt=Logan's Meadow]] |{{convert| 1.1 |ha|acre}} | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord| 52.212 | 0.141 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Logan's Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 463 592 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271084815%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1125 Details] |This site of the bank of the [[River Cam]] has pasture with tortoiseshell and comma butterflies, and flowers such as [[cow parsley]] and [[cuckoo flower]]s. [[Starling]] roost in trees in the autumn, and there are [[freshwater mussel]]s in the river.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1125|title=Logan's Meadow|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=20 February 2013|accessdate=15 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816121943/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1125|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Mare Fen]] |[[File:Mare Fen, drying out - geograph.org.uk - 783079.jpg|100px|alt=Mare Fen]] |{{convert| 16.3 |ha|acre}} | [[Swavesey]]
{{coord| 52.309 | 0.002 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Mare Fen }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 366 698 }} |[[South Cambridgeshire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009020%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=284 Details] |This pasture in the floodplain of the [[River Great Ouse]] is used for grazing in the summer and allowed to flood in the winter. It has wildfowl such as [[mute swan]]s, [[wigeon]]s, [[Eurasian teal|teal]] and [[Northern shoveler|shovelers]], mammals include badgers and [[muntjac deer]]. There are diverse aquatic plants.{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/directory_record/3216/mare_fen|title=Mare Fen|publisher=Cambridgeshire County Council|accessdate=15 December 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220172657/http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/directory_record/3216/mare_fen|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Melwood Local Nature Reserve|Melwood]] |[[File:Melwood Local Nature Reserve 5.jpg|100px|alt=Melwood]] |{{convert|0.6 |ha|acre}} | [[Meldreth]]
{{coord| 52.095 | 0.011 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Melwood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 378 459 }} |[[South Cambridgeshire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271100048%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1165 Details] |This is a woodland site next to the [[River Mel]], with trees such as ash, hawthorn, sycamore, beech and silver birch. Ground flora include [[Viola riviniana|dog violet]] and [[cow parsley]], while [[Clematis vitalba|traveller's joy]] provides food for moths. [[Tawny owl]]s and [[pipistrelle bat]]s roost on ivy.{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/directory_record/3215/melwood|title=Local Nature Reserves : Melwood|publisher=Cambridgeshire County Council|accessdate=2 October 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20140723172654/http%3A//www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/directory_record/3215/melwood|archivedate=23 July 2014|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Nine Wells]] |[[File:Within Nine Wells LNR - geograph.org.uk - 751806.jpg|100px|alt=Nine Wells]] |{{convert| 1.2 |ha|acre}} | [[Great Shelford]]
{{coord|52.167 | 0.135 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Nine Wells }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 461 542 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271084816%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1124 Details] |The springs in this beech wood feed [[Hobson's Conduit]], which formerly supplied clean drinking water to Cambridge. It was previously an [[SSSI]] for its rare invertebrates, but these were lost during the drought of 1976 and it forfeited its SSSI status. 108 species of flora have been recorded.{{cite web|url=http://lnr.cambridge.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/ninewells_mngplan.pdf|title=Nine Wells LNR, Summary Management Plan, 2007-2007|publisher=Cambridge City Council|accessdate=16 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003124911/http://lnr.cambridge.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/ninewells_mngplan.pdf|archivedate=3 October 2015|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Paradise Local Nature Reserve|Paradise]] |[[File:Paradise Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 789906.jpg|100px|alt=Paradise]] |{{convert| 2.2 |ha|acre}} | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord| 52.194 | 0.114 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Paradise }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 446 572 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009264%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=531 Details] |This site on the west bank of the [[River Cam]] has marshland and wet woodland with mature willows. Flora include [[butterbur]], and the reserve has the uncommon [[musk beetle]], which lays its eggs in the willows.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=531|title=Paradise|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=20 February 2013|accessdate=16 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816120425/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=531|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ring's End Local Nature Reserve|Ring's End]] |[[File:Ring's End 5.jpg|100px|alt=Ring's End]] |{{convert| 8.5 |ha|acre}} | [[March, Cambridgeshire|March]]
{{coord| 52.595 | 0.069 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Ring’s End }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TF 402 017 }} |[[Fenland District|Fenland]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271100049%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1164 Details] |This is a linear site along a disused railway embankment, with views over [[The Fens]]. There are also three ponds, reedbeds and areas of scrub.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1164 |title=Ring’s End |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=21 February 2013 |accessdate=20 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816141229/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1164 |archivedate=16 August 2016 |df= }} The soil is poor in nutrients, which has allowed uncommon flowering plants such as [[Tussilago|coltsfoot]] to become established.{{cite web|url=http://www4.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/directory_record/3214/rings_end|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20140723172507/http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/directory_record/3214/rings_end|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 July 2014|title=Local Nature Reserves : Ring's End|publisher=Cambridgeshire County Council|accessdate=20 November 2016|df=dmy-all}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sheep's Green and Coe Fen]] |[[File:Coe Fen - geograph.org.uk - 648256.jpg|100px|alt=Coe Fen]] |{{convert| 16.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Cambridge]]
{{coord| 52.197 | 0.116 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sheep's Green and Coe Fen }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 447 575 }} |[[Cambridge]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271481364%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1754 Details] |These seasonally flooded grazing grounds on the banks of the [[River Cam]] have waterfowl such as egrets, kingfishers and herons, and [[European water vole|water voles]] are increasing in numbers. There are a number of mature willow trees.{{cite web|url=http://lnr.cambridge.gov.uk/nature_reserve/sheeps-green-and-coe-fen/|title=Sheep's Green and Coe Fen|publisher=Cambridge City Council|accessdate=16 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220211241/http://lnr.cambridge.gov.uk/nature_reserve/sheeps-green-and-coe-fen/|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Somersham Local Nature Reserve|Somersham]] |[[File:Somersham Local Nature Reserve 1.jpg|100px|alt=Somersham]] |{{convert| 8.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Somersham]]
{{coord| 52.384 | 0.006 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Somersham }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 366 781 }} |[[Huntingdonshire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271460845%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1655 Details] |Habitats in this reserve are a lake, wetland, grassland and woodland. Invertebrates include [[grass snake]]s and [[common lizards]], there are birds such as [[great crested grebe]]s, and flora such as [[red bartsia]] and [[purple loosestrife]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1655 |title=Somersham |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=21 February 2013 |accessdate=4 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816144631/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1655 |archivedate=16 August 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[St Denis Church, East Hatley|St Denis Church (footprint of church only)]] |[[File:Churchstdenis 4216.JPG|100px|alt=St Denis Church, East Hatley]] |{{convert| 0.02 |ha|acre|2}} | [[Hatley, Cambridgeshire|Hatley]]
{{coord| 52.138 | -0.124 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= St Denis Church }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 285 505 }} |[[South Cambridgeshire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009157%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=422 Details] |The churchyard is mainly neutral grassland, but some is [[calcareous]], and its grasses and flowers are diverse.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=422 |title=St Denis Church (footprint of church only) |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=21 February 2013 |accessdate=14 December 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816113538/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=422 |archivedate=16 August 2016 |df= }} Flowers include [[hoary plantain]], [[Leontodon taraxacoides|rough hawkbit]] and [[oxlip]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hatley.info/docs/St-Denis-churchyard-County-Wildlife-Site.pdf|title=The Wildlife Importance of St. Denis’ Churchyard CWS|publisher=Cambridgeshire County Council|accessdate=14 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220193913/http://www.hatley.info/docs/St-Denis-churchyard-County-Wildlife-Site.pdf|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[West Pit]] |[[File:West Pit 2.jpg|100px|alt=West Pit]] |{{convert| 4.3 |ha|acre}}{{cite web|url=http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=siteunitIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271000330%27|title=Map of Cherry Hinton Pit, unit 1|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=16 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171125202637/http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=siteunitIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271000330%27|archivedate=25 November 2017|df=}} | [[Cherry Hinton]]
{{coord| 52.182 |0.169 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= West Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 483 559 }} |[[Cambridge]] |[[SSSI]]{{cite web|url=http://lnr.cambridge.gov.uk/nature_reserve/limekiln-close/|title=West Pit|publisher=Cambridge City Council|accessdate=15 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116183336/http://lnr.cambridge.gov.uk/nature_reserve/limekiln-close/|archivedate=16 January 2017|df=}} |N/Av{{efn|name=cherry}} |N/Av{{efn|name=cherry}} |This former chalk quarry is now steeply sloping woodland with a caravan park in the centre. The woodland has been designated an SSSI due to the presence of a plant on the British [[IUCN Red List|Red List of Threatened Species]], the [[Seseli libanotis|moon carrot]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000331.pdf |title=Cherry Hinton Pit citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=30 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304043220/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000331.pdf |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Woodston Ponds]] |[[File:Woodston Ponds 5.jpg|100px|alt=Woodston Ponds]] |{{convert| 8.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Peterborough]]
{{coord| 52.568 | -0.264 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Woodston Ponds }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 177 980 }} |[[Peterborough]] |[[WTBCN]]{{cite web |url= http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/woodston-ponds |title= Woodston Ponds |publisher= Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate= 20 November 2016 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160407020122/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/woodston-ponds |archivedate= 7 April 2016 |df= dmy-all }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123096%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=5&N=&ID=1214 Details] |The site was formerly settling ponds to remove washings from sugar beet. The east side has a lake with water birds such as [[grey heron]]s, [[tufted duck]]s and [[Aythya ferina|pochards]]. In the west there is a reedbed which has pools and channels, with [[great crested newt]]s and unusual species of water beetle. |} ==See also== *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Cambridgeshire]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|3}} {{coord|52|20|N|0|0|W|region:GB_type:adm1st|display=title}} {{Local Nature Reserves in Cambridgeshire}} {{LNR lists}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Local nature reserves in England]] [[Category:Local Nature Reserves in Cambridgeshire| Local Nature Reserves in Cambridgeshire]] [[Category:Lists of Local Nature Reserves]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Ranunculus'' species}} '''''[[Ranunculus]]''''' is a [[genus]] of about 600 [[species]] of [[plant]]s in the [[Ranunculaceae]]. Members of the genus include the '''buttercups''', '''spearworts''', '''water crowfoots''' and the [[lesser celandine]]. {{Compact ToC}} ==List of species== === A === {| class="wikitable" |- ! width=350 | Species & Synonyms ! width=200 | Common Names ! width=200 | Native Range ! width=150 | Illustration |- |colspan="4"|''Ranunculus abaensis'' {{small|[[Wen Tsai Wang|W.T.Wang]] 1987}} = ''[[Ranunculus indivisus|R. indivisus]]'' var.
